On each tusk, he transformed into seven ponds, in each pond he transformed into seven lotus flowers, on each flower he transformed into seven terraces, on each terrace he transformed into seven canopied nets, in each net there were seven celestial maidens, each celestial maiden had seven attendants, and each attendant had seven female musicians.
After making these transformations, he went to the cities of the gods.
The thirty-two transformed heads, the thirty-two ministers and their retinue rode on them, and Indra and his retinue rode on the real head.

In this way, there were a total of ten thousand celestial families, their bodies light and floating like blades of grass blown by a whirlwind, riding through the air to the place of play. At that time, the gods did not see each other in front or behind.
When they arrived at the place of play, the gods each went to the gardens and forests for amusement and enjoyed themselves to their heart's content.
At that time, the dragon king also transformed his body into the form of a celestial being and enjoyed himself.

In this way, the power of the Iá¹‡Äbala dragon king is in the body of the bodhisattva. There are eighteen major joints, and each major joint has the power of a thousand Iá¹‡Äbala dragon kings. Such is called the physical strength of the bodhisattva.
There are also those who say that this explanation is still insufficient.

The physical strength of the bodhisattva has eighteen major joints. What was explained before is the strength of the lowest joint of the bodhisattva. The second explanation is the strength of the next best joint of the bodhisattva. The third explanation is the strength of the third joint. In this way, each is progressively stronger.
The Venerable VatthÄyana said:
The power of the mind is immeasurable. One should know that the power of the body is also immeasurable.
How do we know this?
As the path to supreme perfect enlightenment is in the future, it will definitely arise in the present. At that time, the great earth of the trichiliocosm will quake.
For this reason, we know that the power of the mind is immeasurable, and the power of the body is also immeasurable.
Question:
If that is so, why is it said that the Bodhisattva has the power of Narayana?
Answer:
The power of Narayana is what people in the world admire, so it is used as a metaphor.
However, the power of the mind is immeasurable, and the power of the body is also immeasurable.
Question:
For what reason do Bodhisattvas cultivate such power?
Answer:
In order to manifest that everything is supreme.
Just as the Bodhisattva is supreme in all matters in the world, namely in appearance, family, wealth, retinue, accumulated merits and fame, his power should also be so.
Just as appearance, family, etc. benefit the world, his power should also be so.
Furthermore, some say it is for the sake of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Why is it so?
Anuttara-samyak-sambodhi should abide in such a firm body, but it is not possible to say so because of discrimination.
If anuttara-samyak-sambodhi abides on the peak of Mount Sumeru, then Mount Sumeru would be destroyed, because of the power and fearlessness of great respect.
Therefore, when the TathÄgata first attained enlightenment, he raised his foot to walk, and as he slowly stepped on the ground, the earth trembled.

Furthermore, some say that because of anuttara-samyak-sambodhi, in the trichiliocosm, in JambudvÄ«pa, there is a vajra seat that naturally appears. The bodhisattva sits on it and attains perfect enlightenment.
In this way, it is also for the sake of anuttara-samyak-sambodhi that a firm body is accumulated.

There is also a saying that this power attracts sentient beings who are to be transformed. Here, the metaphor of the power of transformation, the metaphor of the ÅšÄkyas shooting arrows, and the metaphor of the solid rock at the time of parinirvÄá¹‡a should be explained.
It is heard that when the World-Honored One was about to enter parinirvÄá¹‡a, he went to the village of PÄpÄ. At that time, five hundred strong men were repairing the road.
There was a rock, twelve zhang long and six zhang wide, which the strong men, to the utmost of their physical strength, were unable to move.
When the World-Honored One arrived, he asked the young men:
What are you doing now?
They replied:
We are repairing the road.
The World-Honored One asked again:
Shall I remove this rock for you now?
They replied:
Yes, please.
The Buddha told the people:
You should all go far away.
At that time, the World-Honored One lifted the large rock with his big toe, placed it in his right palm, and then threw it into the sky with his hand.
He then caught it again and blew it apart with his mouth, scattering it into tiny particles. The scattered particles reassembled and became as they were before, without any difference.
At that time, the strong men asked the Buddha:
What kind of power is this?
The World-Honored One replied:
Lifting it with my big toe and placing it in my palm is the power of the body born from my parents.
Later, throwing it into the sky with my hand is also the power of the body born from my parents.
Blowing it apart with my mouth and scattering it into tiny particles is the power of spiritual penetrations.
Scattering it and having it reassemble as it was before without any difference is the power of liberation.
At that time, the strong men asked the Buddha again:
Is there any power that surpasses the World-Honored One's power?
The Buddha replied:
Yes, it is the power of impermanence.
The Buddha told the strong men:
Whether it is the power of the body born from parents, the power of spiritual penetrations, or the power of liberation, tonight at midnight it will be destroyed by the power of impermanence.
At that time, the strong men, hearing this, gave rise to disgust and renunciation.
The Buddha expounded the Dharma for them, and they attained the realization of the truth.
Therefore, in order to attract and transform sentient beings, they cultivate and perfect this power.
Question:
When do bodhisattvas fully perfect this power?
Answer:
When bodhisattvas are twenty-five years old, they fully perfect this power.
From then until they are fifty years old, their power does not diminish.
After that, their power gradually decreases.
There are also those who say that their power does not diminish.
Why is this?
Because their mental power does not diminish, their physical power is also like that.
The judges say:
It should be said:
The Dharma body does not diminish, but the born body does diminish, because it is a retribution.
As UdÄyin said:
Now I see that the World-Honored One's physical appearance has diminished... and so on at length.
Question:
Do other sentient beings have the power of NÄrÄyaá¹‡a?
Answer:
As explained at the beginning, other beings do not even have the power of a bodhisattva, let alone the rest.

However, when the world was first formed, there were beings in the world with the strength of a NÄrÄyaá¹‡a, half the strength of a NÄrÄyaá¹‡a, the strength of a PÄrijÄta, and those with great strength filling the entire JambudvÄ«pa.
Question:
How are the bones and joints of those people connected?
Answer:
Except for those four kinds of people, the bones and joints of other beings are far apart.
If a person's strength is equal to that of an elephant or horse, their bones and joints are close.
Those with great strength have bones that touch.ğŸ”½Those with the strength of a PÄrijÄta have bones and joints that hook together.
Those with the strength of a NÄrÄyaá¹‡a have bones and joints that are connected like chains.
The bones and joints of bodhisattvas are coiled like dragons, like the horns of a rhinoceros. The pratyekabuddhas are called those with great strength.
Question:
Do the wheel-turning kings have the strength of a NÄrÄyaá¹‡a or not?
Answer:
The power of the wheel-turning king is not that of NÄrÄyaá¹‡a. The power of the king's body and the other treasures are also like this.
If the wheel is gold, the king rules the four continents, and his power is supreme.ğŸ”½If the wheel is silver, the king rules three continents, and his power gradually decreases.
If the wheel is copper, the king rules two continents, and his power decreases further.
If the wheel is iron, the king rules one continent, and his power is weakest.
When the Buddha was in the world, there were three people with the power of a PÄá¹Å›u jar:
One was Venerable Ä€nanda;
The second was the ÅšÄkya son of Åšambhaka;
The third was the ÅšÄkya woman Gaupaki.
Question:
Do pratyekabuddhas appear in the world alone or do they appear together?
Answer:
Some say they appear alone and not together.
Why is it so?

The faculties of pratyekabuddhas are superior to those of ÅšÄriputra. Even if ÅšÄriputra were to appear in the world together with [a pratyekabuddha], such a thing would not happen, let alone five hundred people with meritorious qualities appearing together.
Question:
If pratyekabuddhas do not appear in the world together, and it is said that five hundred people with meritorious qualities appear in the world at the same time, who are they?
Answer:
These are all originally Å›rÄvakas who awaken to bodhi through conditions, and are therefore called pratyekabuddhas.
If they are originally of the pratyekabuddha type and achieve the state of a pratyekabuddha through practice, they appear in the world alone, and should be known as being like a buddha.
The physical strength of the TathÄgata has already been explained. Now, the mental strength will be explained.
The TathÄgata has ten powers, namely the power of knowledge of what is possible and impossible, up to the power of knowledge of the destruction of defilements.
Question:
What is the essence of power?
Answer:
Its essence is knowledge, and its substance is the body of knowledge.
The essence has already been explained. Now, the reason will be explained.
What is the meaning of power?
Answer:
The meaning of not being subdued by others is the meaning of power.
The meaning of not being covered by others is the meaning of power.
The meaning of not being cut off or subdued is the meaning of power.
The meaning of harming, the meaning of definite knowledge, the meaning of being able to bear, and the meaning of supremacy are the meaning of power.
As for realms, the power of knowledge of past lives and the power of knowledge of future destinies are in the form realm, while the other powers are in the desire realm.
If they are contaminated, they are bound to the three realms, but if they are uncontaminated, they are unbound.
As for stages, the power of knowledge of past lives and the power of knowledge of future destinies are in the fundamental four dhyana stages, while the other powers are in the eleven stages.
If they are contaminated, they are in the eleven stages, but if they are uncontaminated, they are in the nine stages.

As for basis, they are based on a body in the desire realm.ğŸ”½As for practice, the power of knowledge of what is possible and impossible up to the power of knowledge of all paths practices the sixteen aspects, but also practices what is not the sixteen aspects.
The power of knowledge of the ripening of karma and the power of knowledge of the methods of practice practice the eight aspects, but also practice what is not the eight aspects.
The third, fourth, fifth, and sixth powers of knowledge, when functioning, function in twelve ways, and also in non-functioning ways.
The power of knowledge of past lives and the power of knowledge of death and rebirth, function in non-functioning ways.

The power of knowledge of the destruction of defilements, if taken as an object, functions in four ways; if taken as present in the body, it functions in sixteen ways, and also in non-functioning ways.
As for the objects of cognition, the power of knowledge of what is possible and impossible takes all dharmas as its object.
The power of knowledge of the ripening of karma and the power of knowledge of the concentrations, emancipations, etc. take the truth of suffering and the truth of origination as their objects.
The third, fourth, fifth, and sixth powers of knowledge take three truths as their objects, excluding the truth of cessation.
The power of knowledge of the path leading everywhere takes the four truths as its objects.
The power of knowledge of past lives takes the five aggregates of the desire and form realms in past lives as its objects.
The power of knowledge of death and rebirth takes the form sense-field as its object.
The power of knowledge of the destruction of defilements, if taken as an object, takes the truth of cessation as its object;
if taken as present in the body, it takes all dharmas as its objects.
The mindfulness of dharmas is the power of knowing desires and the power of knowing past lives.
The power of knowing birth and death is the mindfulness of the body.
The power of knowing the destruction of defilements, if taken as its object, is the mindfulness of dharmas.
If taken as being in the body, it is the four mindfulnesses.
The remaining powers are the four mindfulnesses.
The ten knowledges are the power of knowing what is possible and impossible up to the power of knowing all paths.
The power of knowing the accumulation of dharmas and actions is eight knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path.
The third, fourth, fifth, and sixth powers are nine knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation.
The power of knowing past lives, according to the old Abhidharma masters, is conventional knowledge.
The Venerable VÄtsyÄyana says it is four knowledges:
knowledge of dharmas, inferential knowledge, knowledge of suffering, and conventional knowledge.
The Venerable Ghoá¹£aka says:
It is six knowledges, excluding the knowledge of elimination, the knowledge of non-arising, the knowledge of cessation, and the knowledge of others' minds.
The judges say:
It should be explained as before, that one kind of knowledge is good.
The power of knowledge of birth and death, the old Abhidharma masters say it is one kind of knowledge.
The Venerable Vapu has said it is four kinds of knowledge:
knowledge of dharmas, inferential knowledge, knowledge of accumulation, and knowledge of equality;
the one of true meaning is one kind of knowledge.

The power of knowledge of the destruction of defilements, if it is taken as the object, it is six kinds of knowledge, excluding knowledge of others' minds, knowledge of suffering, knowledge of accumulation, and knowledge of the path;
if it is taken as present in the body, then there are ten kinds of knowledge.
Why is this?
Because these ten kinds of knowledge can all be attained in the TathÄgata's body.
As for the faculties, in general they are associated with three faculties.

As for the past, future, and present, these are dharmas of the three time periods. As for the power of knowledge of the possible and impossible up to the power of knowledge of all paths, they take the three time periods as objects and also take what is not of the three time periods as objects.
The second, third, fourth, fifth, and sixth powers of knowledge take the three time periods as objects.
As for the power of knowledge of past abodes, the past and present [knowledge] takes the past and future worlds as objects.
The knowledge of future birth takes the past world as object, while the knowledge of non-birth takes the three worlds as object.
As for the power of knowledge of the destruction of defilements, the past [knowledge] takes the past world as object;
the present [knowledge] takes the present world as object;
the future knowledge of future birth takes the future world as object;
the knowledge of non-birth takes the three worlds as object.
As for the power of knowledge of the destruction of defilements, if it takes the realm as object, it takes the non-worldly dharma as object;
if it takes what is present in the body as object, it takes the three worlds and the non-worldly as object.
As for the wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate [dharmas], it takes the wholesome as object.
The unwholesome and indeterminate [dharmas] are known. The power of knowledge of dhyÄna, liberation, and samÄdhi takes the wholesome and indeterminate as object.
As for the power of knowledge of the destruction of defilements, if it takes the realm as object, it takes the wholesome as object;
if it takes what is present in the body as object, it takes the wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate as object.
The remaining powers take the three kinds as object.
As for the realms, the power of knowledge of past abodes and the power of knowledge of the destruction of defilements are bound to the form realm;
The remaining powers, if contaminated, are bound to the three realms; if uncontaminated, they are unbound.

Those that take the bound to the three realms as objects are the power of knowledge of past lives and the power of knowledge of death and rebirth, which take the bound to the desire and form realms as objects;
the power of knowledge of the arising of karma and dharmas takes the bound to the three realms as objects.
The power of knowledge of the destruction of defilements, if taken as objects, takes the unbound as objects;
if taken as present in the body, it takes the bound to the three realms and the unbound as objects.
The remaining powers take the bound to the three realms and the unbound as objects.
As for whether they are learners, post-learners, or neither learners nor post-learners, the power of knowledge of past lives;
the power of knowledge of death and rebirth is neither a learner nor a post-learner;
the remaining powers, if uncontaminated, are post-learners; if contaminated, they are neither learners nor post-learners.
As for taking learners, post-learners, and neither learners nor post-learners as objects, the power of knowledge of the arising of karma and dharmas and the power of knowledge of past lives;
the power of knowledge of death and rebirth take neither learners nor post-learners as objects.
The power of knowledge of the destruction of defilements, if taken as objects, takes neither learners nor post-learners as objects;
If it is in the body, it can perceive all three kinds.
The remaining powers perceive all three kinds.
The power of knowledge of past lives and the power of knowledge of future destinies are eliminated in the path of cultivation.
The remaining powers, if contaminated, are eliminated in the path of cultivation;

if uncontaminated, they are not eliminated.ğŸ”½The power of knowledge of the arising of dharmas through the causes and conditions of karma perceives what is eliminated in the path of seeing, what is eliminated in the path of cultivation, and what is not eliminated.

The power of knowledge of past lives perceives what is eliminated in the path of seeing and what is eliminated in the path of cultivation.ğŸ”½The power of knowledge of future destinies perceives what is eliminated in the path of cultivation.
The power of knowledge of the destruction of defilements, if taken as an object, perceives what is not eliminated;
if it is in the body, it perceives all three kinds.
The remaining powers perceive all three kinds.
The power of knowledge of desires and the power of knowledge of future destinies perceive names and meanings.
The power of knowledge of the destruction of defilements perceives meanings.
If taken as an object, it perceives meanings;
if it is in the body, it perceives names and meanings.
The remaining powers also perceive names and meanings.
As for the power of knowledge of what is possible and what is impossible, it takes one's own body, the bodies of others, and non-bodies as objects.
Up to the power of knowledge of all paths and destinations, it takes one's own body, the bodies of others, and also non-body dharmas as objects.
As for the power of knowledge of the destruction of contaminants, if it is taken as an object, it takes non-bodies as objects;
if it is present in the body, it takes all three as objects.
The remaining powers take one's own body and the bodies of others as objects.
Question:
Do these powers arise from skillful means or are they attained through detachment?
Answer:
It can be said that they arise from skillful means and are also attained through detachment.
Why is this?
Because they arise from the skillful means accumulated over three incalculable eons, it is said they arise from skillful means;
because they are attained through detachment from the desire for the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception, it is said they are attained through detachment.
Question:
Where do these powers arise?
Answer:
They arise based on a body in the desire realm, in JambudvÄ«pa and not in other regions.
They are based on a male body, not a female body.
Question:
What is the difference between the power of knowledge of the accumulation of dharmas and the power of knowledge of death and rebirth?
Answer:
From coarse to fine is the power of knowledge of death and rebirth, from fine to coarse is the power of knowledge of the accumulation of dharmas.
As with coarse and fine, visible and invisible, cause and effect, should be understood in the same way.
Having explained the powers and fearlessnesses, now the three knowledges and full enlightenment are explained, up to the four kinds of fearlessness, and so on.
Question:
What is the essential nature of fearlessness?
Answer:
The essential nature is the body of wisdom.
The first power is the first fearlessness, the tenth power is the second fearlessness, the second power is the third fearlessness, and the seventh power is the fourth fearlessness.
Each power includes the four fearlessnesses, and each fearlessness includes the ten powers, so there are forty powers and forty fearlessnesses.
The Buddha spoke in brief, saying that he has accomplished the ten powers and four fearlessnesses;
If explained extensively, it is the accomplishment of forty powers and forty fearlessnesses.
The essence has already been explained, now I will explain what is meant by fearlessness.
The answer is:
The meaning of being unmoved is the meaning of fearlessness;
The meaning of being courageous is the meaning of fearlessness;
The meaning of not being timid is the meaning of fearlessness;
The meaning of peace and security, purity, and complete whiteness is the meaning of fearlessness.
The question is:
Are power and fearlessness the same or different?
The answer is:
All powers are all fearlessnesses.
As explained above, the first power is the first fearlessness, and so on.
The question is:
If that is so, what is the difference between power and fearlessness?
The answer is:
There is no difference.
As it is said, fearlessness is power, and power is fearlessness.
There is also a saying that the names are different.
Why is it so?
This is called power, and this is called fearlessness.
There is also an explanation that when this power was first established, it was already established as the fearlessness.
Furthermore, being firm and strong is power, and being courageous and decisive is fearlessness.
Furthermore, not being subdued by others is power, and not being timid is fearlessness.
Furthermore, wisdom is power, and accomplishment is fearlessness.
Furthermore, the cause is power, and the effect is fearlessness.ğŸ”½Furthermore, not being covered by others is power, and being able to cover others is fearlessness.
Furthermore, benefiting oneself is power, and benefiting others is fearlessness.
Benefiting oneself and benefiting others are also like this.
Furthermore, self-realization is power, and teaching others is fearlessness.ğŸ”½Accumulation is power, and enjoyment is fearlessness.
Receiving wealth and meaning is power, and distributing wealth and meaning is fearlessness.
Furthermore, knowing medical prescriptions is power, and curing others' illnesses is fearlessness.
Furthermore, the unobstructed understanding of the Dharma and its meaning is power, and the unobstructed eloquence in speech is fearlessness.
Furthermore, praising the unobstructed understanding of the Dharma and its meaning is power, while praising the unobstructed understanding of expression and eloquence is fearlessness.
The other distinctions are explained in the same way as in the section on the powers.
The TathÄgata has great compassion.
Question:
What is the essence of great compassion?
Answer:
It is wisdom.
There are also those who say it is illumination.
The judges say:
One should not say this, the previous explanation is better.

It should be known that great compassion is the power of knowing the possible and impossible. The level is the fourth dhyÄna level. The other distinctions should be explained according to their characteristics.
Question:
Why only the powers, fearlessnesses, and great compassion are mentioned here, and not the three foundations of mindfulness?
Answer:
These three are supreme in the aspect of expounding the Dharma;
The three foundations of mindfulness are not like this.
Expounding the powers manifests one's own meaning, expounding the fearlessnesses manifests the subduing of others, and great compassion gives rise to the mind that wishes to expound the Dharma;
The three foundations of mindfulness are not so, therefore they are not mentioned.
The TathÄgata also speaks of accomplishing seven dharmas.
Those seven dharmas should be known as the power of what is possible and impossible.
If the TathÄgata has any other unshared dharmas, they should all be known as the power of what is possible and impossible.
Question:
Are these seven of the nature of how many knowledges?
Answer:
Knowing the Dharma, knowing the measure, and knowing the assembly - this is one kind of knowledge.

As for knowing the meaning, those who say that nirvÄá¹‡a is the ultimate truth have the nature of six knowledges, excluding the knowledge of suffering and accumulation, the knowledge of others' minds, and the knowledge of the path.
Those who say that all dharmas are the ultimate truth have the nature of ten knowledges. Knowing the time and knowing people have the nature of nine knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation.
Knowing oneself has the nature of eight knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of others' minds.
The Venerable VÄseá¹­á¹­ha said:
One knows for oneself that these are the natures of the four knowledges, namely, knowledge of dharmas, inferential knowledge, knowledge of the path, and knowledge of equality.
The judges say:
Such explanations as these may be reasonable, but the meaning of the seven dharmas spoken of in that sÅ«tra is one: knowledge of equality.
The TathÄgata has five holy knowledges and samÄdhis, which are also the power of knowledge of proper and improper.
